name: NewYorker
text:
“This September seems to be the ultimate test of whether we really, truly, finally have run out of outrage,” @sbg1 writes.
 https://t.co/xXAPkgE0Kx

name: NewYorker
text: Faced with the prospect of losing power, the President has gone beyond mere scaremongering and resorted to fomenting unrest from the White House. https://t.co/nBmKC3rO8S

name: NewYorker
text: How Urvashi Pitre, a Dallas-based food blogger fondly known as “Butter-Chicken Lady,” realized that the Instant Pot was a natural match for Indian cooking. https://t.co/mPQRIRcgKt

name: NewYorker
text: "We still have to pay a lot more attention to how sexual harassment and assault affect the most vulnerable and marginalized women and not just high-profile, typically white, beautiful Hollywood actresses," @kate_manne says. https://t.co/g1p73IIOr2

name: NewYorker
text: What unites Jessica Krug’s various adopted identities is her affinity for Blackness as an instrument of authenticity as she made her way through academia. https://t.co/K0AsrJKLUW

name: NewYorker
text:
The best-selling writer Susanna Clarke, whose novel “Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell” is set in an alternative version of England during the Regency period, says she feels more at home in the 19th century than she does in the present. 
https://t.co/CvZDjr62bY

name: NewYorker
text: “whose books? | whose books / did you burn? | / reader, I burnt yours.” A poem by Simon Armitage. https://t.co/dz4LyzKc1g

name: NewYorker
text: A panic in the sugar industry—over new nutrition standards, regulatory pressure, and public sentiment—has prompted a race to not just develop a substitute, but to design a better sugar altogether. https://t.co/ErCluO4BA4

name: NewYorker
text: The coronavirus has revealed to many the geography of class in America, showing that where we live and work shapes whether we live or die. Might it offer a similar lesson about where we learn? https://t.co/gTNFjSOlZJ

name: NewYorker
text: Some scholars question how personal Sappho's erotic poems actually are. https://t.co/sqqOAgl9Im

name: NewYorker
text: The star of HBO Max’s “Raised by Wolves” says he prefers working on his cattle ranch to “putting on makeup and playing make-believe.” https://t.co/0TXxK8fHpi

name: NewYorker
text: Carefully balanced rock towers make a pretty picture, but the proliferation of cairns, fuelled by social media, has negative consequences for the environment. https://t.co/WkkVsXU9Oi

name: NewYorker
text: Calvin Tomkins on the many delights of the artist Pipilotti Rist’s videos. “What Rist delivers in abundance is pleasure, something that has been out of bounds in contemporary art since the 1970s.” https://t.co/4xLonEqI9W

name: NewYorker
text: At President Trump's campaign rallies, the mood remains exuberant, despite the new state of public-health emergency, economic crisis, and popular protest. https://t.co/u24uyAGI6w

text: “You can do anything anywhere! That’s the toilet! And that’s the toilet!” https://t.co/bSqViN45Vm

name: NewYorker
text: Marilynne Robinson calls her style of writing cosmic realism, a patient chronicling of the astonishing nature of existence. Her writing is best understood as a grand project of restoration, aesthetic as well as political. https://t.co/pvXVKw9zNS

name: NewYorker
text:
The feminist writer and social critic, bell hooks, discusses the paranormal world, the public’s fixation on butts, and what it’s like to be a dissident intellectual. She was born on this day in 1952.
https://t.co/TEtLuwyRCx

name: NewYorker
text:
"The Supreme Court has tended, for most of its history, toward a fundamental conservatism, siding with tradition over more expansive visions of human rights," @KeeangaYamahtta writes.
https://t.co/YvE5DThFj9

name: NewYorker
text:
President Trump’s strong-arm effort to force a sale of the Chinese social platform’s U.S. operations has resulted in little discernible improvement in data security, @eosnos writes.
https://t.co/WbgpppwzIc

name: NewYorker
text: .@eunicehcho, a senior staff attorney at the A.C.L.U., discusses the dangers that immigrant women face at poorly run detention facilities. https://t.co/6t1lWldvh5

name: NewYorker
text: RT @cncep: Truly an honor to profile Marilynne Robinson for the @NewYorker. Her new novel, “Jack,” is out next week. https://t.co/6dD3gpRBrs

name: NewYorker
text: The Borowitz Report: “Donald Trump is a man who enjoys watching television,” Barack Obama told reporters. “What if, on Inauguration Day, he picks up the remote and nothing comes on?” https://t.co/NW88hBJ7e5
